free_text.Learning outcomes: The goal of this course is to provide the students with a broad background in state of the art signal processing of speech.  This will include formalisms and methods for analysis and statistical modeling.
free_text.Content: 1. Auditory and computational perception. [br/]Computational and biological auditory models.  Cochlear processing.  Fourier analysis.  Critical band analysis.[br/]2. Auditory production. [br/]Computational and biological models of speech production. Introductory acoustic phonetics.  Linear prediction.  Harmonic plus noise models.  Overlap-add.  Generalised cepstra.[br/]3. Statistical modeling of speech. [br/]Mixture models.  Bayesian methods.  Expectation maximisation (but not HMMs).  Decorrelation.  Dynamic features.[br/]4. Robustness in modeling speech signals.[br/]Effects of room, channel, speaker and noise.  Speech enhancement.  Statistics of speech and noise.  Cepstral normalization.  Vocal tract normalization.  RASTA.  Voice Activity Detection.[br/]5. Laboratory exercises in speech analysis, enhancement, voice activity detection and diarisation.[br/]
free_text.Required prior knowledge: Undergraduate level mathematics and signal processing, including Fourier transforms, linear filters and probability theory.  Programming in Matlab or similar.
